message_1: Consider a knot in 3-dimensional space that has 8 crossings. Determine the minimum number of times this knot must intersect itself in order to become an unknotted loop.
message_2:
To determine the minimum number of times a knot with 8 crossings must intersect itself to become an unknotted loop, we can use the concept of knot unknotting number.

The unknotting number of a knot is the minimum number of times it must be passed through itself to untangle it into an unknotted loop. For a knot with n crossings, the unknotting number can be estimated using the inequality:

Unknotting number ≥ (Crossing number - 1) / 2

In this case, the knot has 8 crossings, so the inequality becomes:

Unknotting number ≥ (8 - 1) / 2
Unknotting number ≥ 7 / 2

Since the unknotting number must be an integer, we round up to the nearest whole number:

Unknotting number ≥ 4

Therefore, the minimum number of times this knot with 8 crossings must intersect itself to become an unknotted loop is 4 times.
